articles.headline: Small Cheesemaker Defies F.D.A. Over Recall
articles.snippet: Estrella Family Creamery’s battle is symbolic of a larger fight between small food producers and regulators.
articles.abstract: Estrella Family Creamery’s battle is symbolic of a larger fight between small food producers and regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONTESANO, Wash.  The foodies raved. The feds raided.

articles.headline: Dear S.E.C., Please Make Brokers Accountable to Customers
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. is considering making stock and insurance brokers put their customers’ interests first. Here’s why it should write that rule.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. is considering making stock and insurance brokers put their customers’ interests first. Here’s why it should write that rule.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dear Mary Schapiro:

articles.headline: Haitians Plunge Into Muck to Stem Cholera
articles.snippet: Workers must clean out by hand the canals and ditches that pass as Haiti’s sewers, dealing with the squalor that helps spread cholera.
articles.abstract: Workers must clean out by hand the canals and ditches that pass as Haiti’s sewers, dealing with the squalor that helps spread cholera.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Duquesne Fils-Aimé, stripped to the waist, stepped gingerly into the canal, drawing stares of astonishment from the spectators above. When he ducked his head under the water  if one could call it that  an audible gasp rose from the crowd.

articles.headline: TV Channel Draws Viewers, and Threats, in Iran
articles.snippet: The campaign against Farsi1 illustrates the growing fear in Iran over the intrusion of private broadcasters onto the country’s airwaves.
articles.abstract: The campaign against Farsi1 illustrates the growing fear in Iran over the intrusion of private broadcasters onto the country’s airwaves.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  In little more than a year, the Persian-language satellite television channel beamed into Iran by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation and a prominent Afghan family has rapidly become one of the most popular stations in the country.

articles.headline: A New Look in Detroit for the Newly Public G.M.
articles.snippet: General Motors is completing its makeover, which includes reducing the government’s stake in the company and changing its signs.
articles.abstract: General Motors is completing its makeover, which includes reducing the government’s stake in the company and changing its signs.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  It is out with the old and in with the new at General Motors as the federal government’s ownership stake in the company was cut in half this week. Even the automaker’s sign atop its corporate headquarters has gotten a makeover.

articles.headline: Unions Yield on Wage Scales to Preserve Jobs
articles.snippet: Union workers are reluctantly agreeing to contracts that create two levels of pay on a permanent, rather than temporary, basis.
articles.abstract: Union workers are reluctantly agreeing to contracts that create two levels of pay on a permanent, rather than temporary, basis.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE  Organized labor appears to be losing an important battle in the Great Recession.

articles.headline: Justice for Spill Victims, Like It or Not
articles.snippet: It is unlikely that oil spill victims will get a fairer deal in court than the one that is compensating them with money from BP’s $20 billion fund.
articles.abstract: It is unlikely that oil spill victims will get a fairer deal in court than the one that is compensating them with money from BP’s $20 billion fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few days ago, I had breakfast with Kenneth R. Feinberg, the former pay czar and 9/11 fund administrator, who is now grappling with one of the most difficult assignments of his career: doling out as much as $20 billion of BP’s cash to residents of the Gulf Coast who suffered as a result of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill.

articles.headline: NATO Sees Long-Term Role After Afghan Combat
articles.snippet: NATO leaders, backing President Obama’s plan for a phaseout, agreed to run security in Afghanistan until 2014.
articles.abstract: NATO leaders, backing President Obama’s plan for a phaseout, agreed to run security in Afghanistan until 2014.
articles.lead_paragraph: LISBON  NATO and Afghanistan agreed Saturday to the goal of a phased transfer of security responsibility to the Afghan government by the end of 2014, but NATO officials acknowledged that allied forces would remain in Afghanistan, at least in a support role, well beyond that date.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: Trying to Put a Price on Bank Errors
articles.snippet: In its report on the mortgage documentation mess, the Congressional Oversight Panel sees a possible threat to the financial system’s stability.
articles.abstract: In its report on the mortgage documentation mess, the Congressional Oversight Panel sees a possible threat to the financial system’s stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: KUDOS to the Congressional Oversight Panel for publishing a thoughtful and thorough report last week on the mortgage documentation mess. It argued that, yes, in fact, these paperwork problems may have significant implications for banks, investors and the stability of the financial system.

articles.headline: Can QVC Translate Its Pitch Online?
articles.snippet: QVC, the leading TV shopping channel, has discovered that its strong points apply online, too. The task is now to maximize them.
articles.abstract: QVC, the leading TV shopping channel, has discovered that its strong points apply online, too. The task is now to maximize them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST CHESTER, Pa.

articles.headline: Pushing 40, Southwest Is Still Playing the Rebel
articles.snippet: Southwest has become one of the biggest airlines and is turning 40 next year, but it is clinging to a corporate culture of Halloween parties and rapping flight attendants.
articles.abstract: Southwest has become one of the biggest airlines and is turning 40 next year, but it is clinging to a corporate culture of Halloween parties and rapping flight attendants.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dallas

articles.headline: Clues to Stubborn Secret in C.I.A.’s Backyard
articles.snippet: A sculpture at the C.I.A.’s headquarters has a secret code in it, and the artist is now offering a bit of help.
articles.abstract: A sculpture at the C.I.A.’s headquarters has a secret code in it, and the artist is now offering a bit of help.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is perhaps one of the C.I.A.’s most mischievous secrets.

articles.headline: In Rare Cases, Pope Justifies Use of Condoms
articles.snippet: Pope Benedict XVI said that condom use may be appropriate in some cases to help stop the spread of AIDS.
articles.abstract: Pope Benedict XVI said that condom use may be appropriate in some cases to help stop the spread of AIDS.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME  Pope Benedict XVI has said that condom use can be justified in some cases to help stop the spread of AIDS, the Vatican’s first exception to a long-held policy banning contraceptives. The pope made the statement in interviews on a host of contentious issues with a German journalist, part of an unusual effort to address some of the harshest criticisms of his turbulent papacy.
articles.byline: By Rachel Donadio and Laurie Goodstein

articles.headline: North Koreans Unveil New Plant for Nuclear Use
articles.snippet: North Korea showed an American scientist last week a vast new facility it secretly and rapidly built to enrich uranium.
articles.abstract: North Korea showed an American scientist last week a vast new facility it secretly and rapidly built to enrich uranium.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — North Korea showed a visiting American nuclear scientist earlier this month a vast new facility it secretly and rapidly built to enrich uranium, confronting the Obama administration with the prospect that the country is preparing to expand its nuclear arsenal or build a far more powerful type of atomic bomb.

articles.headline: Growing Up Digital, Wired for Distraction
articles.snippet: The constant stream of stimuli offered by new technology poses a profound new challenge to focusing and learning.
articles.abstract: The constant stream of stimuli offered by new technology poses a profound new challenge to focusing and learning.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDWOOD CITY, Calif. — On the eve of a pivotal academic year in Vishal Singh’s life, he faces a stark choice on his bedroom desk: book or computer?

articles.headline: After Months of Resisting, Ireland Applies for Bailout
articles.snippet: The much-anticipated step gave a lift Monday to global stocks, although details of how the multibillion-euro package will work have yet to be worked out.
articles.abstract: The much-anticipated step gave a lift Monday to global stocks, although details of how the multibillion-euro package will work have yet to be worked out.
articles.lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Ireland has formally applied for a rescue package worth more than $100 billion, after months of trying to survive its financial crisis with austerity measures and strict budgetary planning. The much-anticipated step gave a lift Monday to global stocks as well as the euro.

articles.headline: ‘Harry Potter’ Has $330 Million Debut Weekend
articles.snippet: The global sales for the seventh Harry Potter movie was a result of a yearlong full-court press by Warner Brothers.
articles.abstract: The global sales for the seventh Harry Potter movie was a result of a yearlong full-court press by Warner Brothers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The seventh Harry Potter movie opened to a jaw-dropping $330 million in global ticket sales over the weekend, underscoring the magical powers of the Warner Brothers marketing and distribution departments.

articles.headline: For Russia’s Poor, Blond Hair Is Snippet of Gold
articles.snippet: Poverty is common in parts of some former Soviet states. So is blond hair, which is in demand for hair extensions.
articles.abstract: Poverty is common in parts of some former Soviet states. So is blond hair, which is in demand for hair extensions.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSALSK, Russia  The road into town is a potholed track, passing villages of log cabins and fallow fields that speak to the poverty that has gripped this part of central Russia for as long as anyone can remember.

articles.headline: Even Before Friday, Retail Deals Will Go Online
articles.snippet: This Thanksgiving Day, retailers are driving customers to the Web with more specials than ever.
articles.abstract: This Thanksgiving Day, retailers are driving customers to the Web with more specials than ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amanda Thomas Perry used to skip sleeping on Thanksgiving night so she could be at Lowe’s or Wal-Mart before dawn on Friday for the special “door-buster” deals.

articles.headline: Chatroulette Gives Rise to a Genre
articles.snippet: A number of Web entrepreneurs are hoping to spin the concept of serendipity and human connections into business opportunities — while keeping the creep factor to a minimum.
articles.abstract: A number of Web entrepreneurs are hoping to spin the concept of serendipity and human connections into business opportunities — while keeping the creep factor to a minimum.
articles.lead_paragraph: Remember Chatroulette, the Web site that pairs strangers for anonymous video chats? It was all the rage among the Web’s tastemakers early this year.

articles.headline: Administration to Seek Balance in Airport Screening
articles.snippet: Facing criticism for new airport screenings, the Obama administration said that the program is “evolving” but that the measures in place are justified by the risk.
articles.abstract: Facing criticism for new airport screenings, the Obama administration said that the program is “evolving” but that the measures in place are justified by the risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: Caught between complaints that airport screening has become too intrusive and threats of new terror attacks on aviation, Obama administration officials say they are sensitive to criticisms that security measures go too far, but they are insisting that the measures now in place are justified by the risks.

articles.headline: Between Firefights, Jokes, Sweat and Tedium
articles.snippet: Life on the front lines has two sides: the adrenaline-fueled moments of fighting, and the unglamorous everything else.
articles.abstract: Life on the front lines has two sides: the adrenaline-fueled moments of fighting, and the unglamorous everything else.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAHR-i-SUFI, Afghanistan  From his rooftop position, Sgt. Santiago Zapata watched the firefight begin after prayer call ended, a rocket-propelled grenade exploding as the muezzin’s voice was still fading into the Afghan dusk.

articles.headline: A News Corp. Newspaper, but Not in Print
articles.snippet: Rupert Murdoch is building The Daily, a newspaper for iPads that, unlike most news sites and apps, will be published each morning in one great heave, like a newspaper.
articles.abstract: Rupert Murdoch is building The Daily, a newspaper for iPads that, unlike most news sites and apps, will be published each morning in one great heave, like a newspaper.
articles.lead_paragraph: People who own an iPad will tell you it makes everything look sexier. Maybe even a newspaper.

articles.headline: With Kinect Controller, Hackers Take Liberties
articles.snippet: Programmers, roboticists and tinkerers are getting Microsoft’s new Kinect gaming device to do things it was not meant to do.
articles.abstract: Programmers, roboticists and tinkerers are getting Microsoft’s new Kinect gaming device to do things it was not meant to do.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Oliver Kreylos, a computer scientist, heard about the capabilities of Microsoft’s new Kinect gaming device, he couldn’t wait to get his hands on it. “I dropped everything, rode my bike to the closest game store and bought one,” he said.

articles.headline: A Figure at Troubled Companies Has Big Plans for PBS Program
articles.snippet: “Nightly Business Report,” distributed on PBS, is now owned by Mykalai Kontilai, whose decade in public television is dotted with legal problems and soured business deals.
articles.abstract: “Nightly Business Report,” distributed on PBS, is now owned by Mykalai Kontilai, whose decade in public television is dotted with legal problems and soured business deals.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the three months since Mykalai Kontilai and his backers bought one of public broadcasting’s crown jewels, the PBS-distributed “Nightly Business Report,” he has moved with an urgency not usually seen within public television.

articles.headline: 2 Treatments for Retinas Make Gains
articles.snippet: In trials, an experimental drug for macular degeneration succeeded in requiring fewer injections. And a therapy from embryonic stem cells won approval for testing to treat retina disease.
articles.abstract: In trials, an experimental drug for macular degeneration succeeded in requiring fewer injections. And a therapy from embryonic stem cells won approval for testing to treat retina disease.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Elderly people losing their vision from age-related macular degeneration might one day have a treatment option that requires fewer injections into the eye than the standard drug now used.
